title: Tumorigenic cell selection and substrate rigidity manipulation using 2D and 3D extracellular matrices

Step-by-step method details
Fabrications of fibrin gels
Timing: 2 h
Preparation of fibrinogen and cell solution mixture.
Trypsinize cells with TrypLE or trypsin to dissociate and suspend in medium and count cell concentration.
Add appropriate amounts of fibrinogen, cell solution, cell medium, and T7 buffer to get a cells/fibrinogen mixture. Keep the mixture on ice. Different concentrations of fibrinogen form matrices with different stiffness (Liu et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]; Tan et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]). The formula of some frequently-used and stiffness calibrated fibrin gels is shown in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1852_8.csv
Cell seeding in 3D fibrin gels.
Add 5 μL thrombin (0.1 U/μL) to the center of each well (24-well plate).
250 μL mixture of the fibrinogen and cell solution is seeded immediately into each well.
Put the 24-well cell culture plate for 30 min in a 37°C incubator with 5% CO2 until fibrin gel polymerization. The visual workflow of fibrin gels generation is shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]. Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1852-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. The operation flow of fibrin gels generation in a 24-well plate
Add 1mL medium to each well, and put it back into the 5% CO2 incubator.
Carefully remove the old culture medium every two days, and add 1 mL of fresh medium into each well. Tilt the plate slightly during the liquid change to prevent the pipette from disturbing the gels.
Note: Do not allow the gel to wrinkle when mixing fibrinogen and cell solution mixture with thrombin. It is recommended to place the culture plates on ice throughout the process on the premise of ensuring an aseptic operation. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3].
Note: HCT116 cells form smooth and proliferating colonies in 90-Pa 3D fibrin gels (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]). With the increase of gel stiffness, the colony shape becomes smoother, but the growth rate decreases gradually. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5].

Live 3D colony growth monitoring
Timing: 6 days
Colony size and circularity analysis.
Seed 5000 cells into 3D fibrin gels per well in a 24-well plate. Two repeats for each condition.
Capture at least 15 colony images for each condition every two days with a regular widefield microscope.
Analyze Colony size or circularity quantitatively by image J software. Draw the growth curve of colonies based on the measured size or circularity across time.
Colony numbers analysis.
Culture 500 cells into 3D fibrin gels per well in a 96-well plate for each condition. Three repeats for each condition. Count the numbers of round colonies in the wells under the microscope every two days.
Draw the growth curve based on the colony numbers across time.
Note: Culture plates of 3D fibrin gels should be selected according to the specific needs of experiments. The cell numbers seeded in 3D fibrin gels are variable. Make sure that there is still space between colonies after 6 days of culturing without touching each other. The formula of reagents and cell concentrations in different plates is shown in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].
Note: For the experiments that need to detect the colony growth after cell transfection, direct transfection in a 3D fibrin gel system is not recommended, as it is difficult for Lipofectamine to reach cells or colonies through fibrin gel pores. It is recommended to transfect cells before 3D fibrin gels generation.
Note: Capture colony images randomly rather than selectively, and note that the completely spreading tumor cells tend to be differentiated which may not have tumorigenic potential.

3D cultured cell isolation
Timing: 1h

3D cultured colonies or single cells need to be extracted from fibrin gels for subsequent mechanotransductive study. 3D cultured colonies can be used for qPCR and western blotting, while 3D cultured singles cells can be used for immunofluorescence staining(IF), atomic force microscope (AFM) measurement, and flow cytometry.
Fibrin gel degradation.
Take out a Dispase II stock (100 mg/mL) and melt it on the ice. Dilute it to 2mg/mL with PBS.
Take a 24-well plate with fibrin gels and colonies out from the incubator. Remove culture medium and wash with PBS once.
Discard PBS and add 200 μL of Dispase II solution into each well.
Incubate the matrix at 37°C with 5% CO2 for 5–15 min.
After gel degradation, collect the solution to a 15 mL centrifugal tube and centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min to obtain the colonies, which could be used for qPCR, western blotting, and other experiments that do not require single cells.
Colony dissociation.
Disperse the colony pellet in step 5.d with 1 mL of TrypLE. Place the tube in a 37°C water bath.
Disperse the cell mass every 5 min and observe the degree of colony dissociation under the microscope.
When it is observed that the colonies are completely dissociated into single cells, add the culture medium to terminate the digestion. Harvest single cells after centrifugation at 200 × g for 5 min. Troubleshooting 4.[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7]
Single cells can be counted for injection of mice experiments or flow cytometry, or replated onto dishes for high-resolution analysis including single-cell imaging or AFM measurement.

Note: It usually takes 15–20 min to dissociate colorectal colonies into single cells. The whole colonies or single cells harvest process should be controlled within 1 hour, as the physical environment has been altered once fibrin gels degrade. The properties of 3D fibrin gels selected colonies or cells may change due to their plasticity when placed in a tube or rigid plastic well for a long time.
3D cultured cell fixation for fluorescence imaging
Timing: 3 days
Paraformaldehyde fixation.
Seed 5000 cells into 3D fibrin gels on a glass-bottom dish according to the reagent amounts shown in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].
After 2–6 days of culturing, carefully aspirate the culture medium and wash with PBS once.
Add 1 mL 4% Paraformaldehyde to each dish and shake at 25°C–27°C for 10 min.
Wash with PBST (0.05% Triton-X in PBS) on a shaker for 20 min three times.
Pause point: After fixation, the glass bottom dishes with gels and colonies covered with PBS can be stored at 4°C for two weeks.
Immunofluorescence.
Remove PBST and add 500 μL Normal Donkey Serum (blocking serum) to each dish. Block for at least 5 h at 4°C.
Prepare 100–200 μL of primary antibody solution diluted with blocking serum for each glass-bottom dish, and the dilution ratio of primary antibody is about 1:50 to 1:100.
After blocking, remove the blocking buffer and add 100–200 μL primary antibody solution to the center of the glass-bottom dish. Incubate the antibody at 4°C for 5–12 h.
Remove primary antibody and wash with PBST on a shaker for 20 min three times.
Repeat step 8. a and prepare 500 μL of second antibody solution diluted with blocking serum for each glass-bottom dish, and the dilution ratio of the second antibody is 1:1000.

After blocking, remove the blocking buffer and add 500 μL s antibody solution to the center of the glass-bottom dish. Incubate at 25–27°C and protect from light for 2 h.
Remove the second antibody and wash with PBST on a shaker for 20 min three times. The dishes are ready for imaging.
Alternatives: When using dyes such as fluorescent labeled phalloidin or DAPI for fluorescent staining, dye solution can be directly added for staining (skip 8a to g). After 30 min staining, imaging can be carried out after PBST washing for 20 min three times.
Note: During fluorescence imaging, try to focus on the colonies in the middle of the gels instead of those on the bottom. Because colonies on the bottom of gels directly contact the rigid glass of the dish, its properties are different from the tumorigenic cells.
Preparation of PA gels and cell seeding
Timing: 3 days
Preparation of activated glass-bottom dishes.
Add 200 μL 0.1 N NaOH with a pipette to the glass bottom dishes (35 mm with 20 mm glass-bottom well) and air-dry for 10–16 h.
Smear 100–200 μL of 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane evenly on the glass bottom dishes with a sterile q-tip for 6 min.
Rinse with ddH2O on a shaker for 15 min twice with gentle agitation.
Cover the glass with 0.5% glutaraldehyde and incubate at 25°C–27°C for 1h.
Remove the glutaraldehyde, rinse with ddH2O for 15 min twice and remove the ddH2O by aspiration and UV treated Kimwipe paper. The activation steps of glass-bottom dishes have been completed (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1852-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Glass-bottom dishes activation
Critical: NaOH, 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane, and glutaraldehyde are harmful to health. Wear protective gear and operate safely.
Pause point: Activated glass bottom dishes can be stored for 48 h at 25°C–27°C or 2 weeks at 4°C.
Preparation of polyacrylamide Solution.

The gel precursor solution is mixed from 40% acrylamide solution and 2% bis-acrylamide solution in ddH2O, and gels can be polymerized by adding 1/200 volume of 10% APS and 1/2000 volume of TEMED to the precursor solution. PA gels stiffness is controlled by varying amounts of 40% acrylamide and 2% bis-acrylamide solutions (Engler et al., 2004[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]; Yeung et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]; Wang and Pelham, 1998[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]). Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3] shows the formula of PA gels with different stiffness.

Immediately add 40 μL of the precursor solution onto the preactivated glass-bottom dishes and cover with an 18 mm coverslip.
Put inverted dishes 30–40min in a 37°C incubator for acrylamide polymerizing. The time can be adjusted according to the gel stiffness to make sure the polymerization is complete.
Add 2 mL 100 mM HEPES to dishes and remove the coverslip gently using forceps.
Wash the gel with 100 mM HEPES on a shaker for 15 min twice.
Critical: Acrylamide, bis-acrylamide, and APS are harmful to health. Wear protective gear and operate safely.
Note: When preparing the PA gel precursor solution, it is recommended to add reagents in this order: ddH2O → 40% acrylamide solution → 2% bis-acrylamide solution → 10% APS → TEMED. The process of PA gels preparation is shown schematically in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]. Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9].
Pause point: The gels submerged in HEPES could be stored for 2 weeks at 4°C.
Note: HCT116 cells show a tendency of spheroidization on the softer PA gels (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]), which is consistent with our previous finding that soft matrix contributes to the stemness of colorectal cancer cells (Chang et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
Collagen type I coating on PA gel surface.

Figure 3. PA gels generation

Prepare 700 μL Sulfo-SANPAH working solution for each dish by diluting 1 part of 5 mg/mL stock solution with 99 parts of HEPES.
Remove HEPES from the dishes containing gels and add 350 μL Sulfo-SANPAH working solution. Place gels under UV light for 6 min. Ensure that the distance between UV light and PA gels does not exceed 6 cm.
Remove the darkened Sulfo-SANPAH solution and wash with 100 mM HEPES on a shaker for 10 min twice in dark.
Repeat step 11. b and c.
Prepare 350 μL of collagen type I (200 μg/mL) for each dish by diluting the appropriate amount of collagen type I in PBS.
Remove HEPES and incubate with 200 μL 200 μg/mL of collagen type I or fibrinogen at 4°C for 10–16 h.
Wash the gels with PBS carefully. The PA gels coated with Collagen type I are ready for cell seeding and can be stored for 2–3 weeks at 4°C submerged in PBS. The process of gel coating is shown schematically in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1852-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Collagen type I coating and cell seeding on PA gel
Note: Prepare fresh Sulfo-SANPAH working solution before use. Make sure the gels are fully covered with Sulfo-SANPAH. Remove liquids carefully and avoid touching the gels. The gels submerged in PBS can be stored at 4°C for 2 weeks.
Cell seeding.
Sterilize the gels under UV light for at least 30 min. Remove PBS and add cell culture medium to gels. Place gels in a 37°C incubator with 5% CO2 for 35–45 min.
Seed cancer cells onto the PA gels with an appropriate density. Generally, the cells should reach 70% confluence within 2 days. Troubleshooting 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.11].
PA gels cultured cell harvesting
Timing: 1h
Cell digestion.

Culture cells on PA gels for 24–72 h. Remove the culture medium. Troubleshooting 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.13].
Wash the dishes with PBS and digest the cells from PA gels with 500 μL TrypLE for each dish.
Collect PA gels cultured cells by centrifugation at 200 × g for 3 min.
Note: The cells digested from PA gels can be used for most molecular biology experiments. For the single-cell experiment of measuring cell rigidity by atomic force microscope (AFM), it is recommended to replant the single cell on the surface of the glass bottom dish without gels. And the AFM measurement should be finished within 30 min for each dish in case of changes of cells seeded on glass.
